Sumac is a reddish-purple powder made from the dried and ground berries of the wild sumac bush. It has been a staple spice in Middle Eastern and Mediterranean cuisine for thousands of years, used by the ancient Romans as a source of tartness long before lemons were widely available in Europe. It is a key ingredient in the spice blend za'atar. The flavor of sumac is its most prized quality: it is tangy, bright, and lemony, but without the harsh acidity of citrus juice. This unique, fruity tartness provides a surprising and exotic counterpoint to the sweetness of chocolate, cutting through the richness of dark cacao to add a zesty, unexpected kick.
catalogue_ingredient_tan_coffee_text

While Morocco is more famous for its mint tea, it has a long-standing coffee culture centered around its bustling cafés. The beans, typically imported from coffee-growing regions and then roasted locally, are prepared in the Turkish style - finely ground and brewed in a cezve. Moroccan coffee is often spiced with a blend of "ras el hanout" spices, which can include cinnamon, cardamom, and nutmeg. The coffee sourced for Baumeister Confections in Tangier reflects this tradition, offering a robust flavor with a uniquely spicy and aromatic character.
catalogue_ingredient_tea_text

Originating in China, black tea is made from the leaves of the Camellia sinensis plant. It is more oxidized than other tea types like green or oolong, a process which gives it a darker color and a more robust, malty flavor. Its journey to the West, particularly to Britain, made it a global commodity that influenced major historical events and shaped entire economies.

The flavor of black tea can range from malty and earthy to floral and fruity, depending on its origin. The tannins in the tea provide a pleasant astringency that balances the creamy richness of a chocolate ganache. It is a classic choice for infusions, imparting a sophisticated, aromatic character to high-end truffles and exotics.
catalogue_ingredient_toffee_text

Toffee is a confection made by caramelizing sugar or molasses along with butter, and occasionally flour. The mixture is heated to a high temperature, known in confectionery as the "hard crack" stage (149 to 154 °C or 300 to 310 °F), before being cooled to solidify. This results in a hard, brittle candy with a rich, buttery flavor. When broken into chips and mixed into chocolate, toffee provides a delightful textural contrast with its signature crunch and a sweet, buttery flavor that complements the chocolate.
catalogue_ingredient_turmeric_text

A member of the ginger family, turmeric is a rhizome native to the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia. It has been a cornerstone of Ayurvedic medicine for thousands of years and is the spice that gives curry powder its characteristic golden-yellow color. Its role as a dye and a spice made it a valuable commodity in ancient trade.

Turmeric has a warm, bitter, and earthy flavor with a peppery, mustard-like aroma. Its distinct earthiness adds an unexpected savory depth that can balance the sweetness of white chocolate or create a complex, wellness-inspired flavor profile in exotic confections, often paired with other spices like ginger and cardamom.
catalogue_ingredient_vanilla_text

Vanilla is the fruit of an orchid, the only member of its vast family to produce an edible product. It is native to Mexico, where it was first cultivated by the Totonac people. The Aztecs later acquired it and used it to flavor their cacao-based drink, "xocolatl." For centuries, all attempts to cultivate the plant outside of Mexico failed due to its symbiotic relationship with a specific local species of bee.

Far from being a "plain" flavor, true vanilla is incredibly complex, with hundreds of aromatic compounds. In chocolate, it acts as a flavor enhancer, mellowing the bitterness of the cacao and rounding out the overall taste, adding a creamy, floral background note that is fundamental to modern confectionery.
catalogue_ingredient_walnut_text

The English walnut, also known as the Persian walnut, originated in the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It was traded along the Silk Road and highly prized by ancient civilizations, with its cultivation spreading throughout Asia and Europe. The state of California is now one of the world's primary commercial growers and exporters of walnuts.

Walnuts have a distinctive, robust flavor that is earthy and rich, with a characteristic slight bitterness from their papery skin. This tannic quality provides a perfect counterbalance to very sweet confections like fudge, caramel, and brownies, where the nut's assertive flavor and crunchy texture prevent the final product from being one-dimensionally sweet.
catalogue_ingredient_wasabi_text

True wasabi is derived from the rhizome of the Wasabia japonica plant, a member of the same family as mustard and horseradish. It is notoriously difficult to cultivate, as it grows naturally along the beds of mountain streams in Japan. Due to its rarity and high price, most "wasabi" served outside of Japan is actually a mixture of horseradish, mustard, and green food coloring.

Its pairing with chocolate is a bold, modern invention. Wasabi provides a sharp, pungent heat that is felt more in the nasal passages than on the tongue, and which dissipates quickly. This provides a shocking but exhilarating contrast to the sweetness of chocolate, creating a memorable and daring confection for adventurous palates.
catalogue_ingredient_whipped_cream_text

Whipped cream is created by aerating heavy cream, often with a whisk or mixer, until it becomes light and fluffy. The agitation incorporates air bubbles into the liquid, and the fat globules in the cream stick together to form a stiff lattice that traps the air. Often sweetened with sugar and flavored with vanilla, it is a popular topping for desserts and beverages. Its light texture and rich dairy flavor make it an ideal topping for mochas and other specialty coffee drinks, adding a layer of creamy indulgence that contrasts with the bitterness of the coffee.
catalogue_ingredient_whiskey_text

Whiskey is a type of distilled alcoholic beverage made from a fermented grain mash, with varieties including bourbon, rye, scotch, and Irish whiskey. The spirit is almost always aged in wooden casks, which gives it a distinctive range of flavors, often including notes of oak, vanilla, caramel, and smoke.

The pairing of whiskey and chocolate is a modern favorite among connoisseurs. The smoky, complex, and often peaty notes of a good whiskey provide a powerful and sophisticated contrast to the sweetness of chocolate, making it a popular choice for filling high-end truffles and bonbons aimed at an adult palate.
catalogue_port_zurich_text

A major European financial hub, Zürich is the starting point of your journey. Its central location and bustling markets make it a key location for acquiring a wide variety of ingredients. The Zürich Chocolate Works is the first factory you will operate.
